title: AMD Radeon RX 9070 or 9070 XT: I'm buying one of these prebuilt gaming PCs instead of getting scalped
description: So you're after an AMD Radeon RX 9070 / XT? While the price is great, trying to seemingly find one at retail price is about as easy as finding a PS5 in 2020. Instead of paying inflated prices, I'd instead recommend picking up a prebuilt gaming PC—and these Skytech options are some of the best I've seen. Read more
author: Christian Wait
excerpt: As of March 17, you can snag a Skytech prebuilt gaming PC with an AMD Radeon RX 9070 GPU for as low as $1,349.99 at Amazon. The RX 9070 XT models start at $1,59
text: Image credit: RPS Photo Composite / Skytech So you're after an AMD Radeon RX 9070 / XT? While the price is great, trying to seemingly find one at retail price is about as easy as finding a PS5 in 2020. Instead of paying inflated prices, I'd instead recommend picking up a prebuilt gaming PC—and these Skytech options are some of the best I've seen. Prebuilts aren't just for people who don’t want to tinker. These days, buying a prebuilt can actually save you money, especially when GPU stock is this scarce. And let's be real, not everyone has the patience (or technical confidence) to put together a custom rig without something catching on fire. To help you in your search, I've scoured Amazon for the best Skytech gaming PCs featuring the RX 9070 and RX 9070 XT, and here's what I found. For just $1,349.99, this is the cheapest way to get your hands on an RX 9070—and honestly, it's a solid deal. You get an Intel Core i5-14400F (perfectly fine for gaming), 16GB of DDR5 RAM (6000MHz), and a 1TB NVMe SSD. The 650W Gold PSU is technically enough for this build, but I'd prefer something a little beefier. If you plan to add more components later, you might want to upgrade the power supply. That said, if you just want a plug-and-play rig that runs 1440p games at high settings, this is a great deal. Same specs as the Shadow, but this one comes in white. If you’re all about aesthetics and want your setup to look like a futuristic space station, this is your pick. The mesh front panel also improves airflow, which is nice because nobody likes thermal throttling. Downside? It’s $350 more than the Shadow for basically the same internals. You’re paying for the case and cooling improvements. But hey, if looks matter, go for it. Now we're talking. The Skytech Blaze4 swaps in the RX 9070 XT—which, by the way, clears Nvidia's RTX 5070 Ti in most benchmarks. You also get an AMD Ryzen 7 7700, a better 850W Gold PSU, and the same 16GB DDR5 RAM and 1TB SSD. This build is $1,599.99 right now (normally $1,699.99), which makes it one of the best-value RX 9070 XT PCs I’ve seen. If you want 4K gaming without selling a kidney, this is it. Skytech Chronos Gaming PC – $1,899.99 If you have a massive game library (or just hate deleting stuff), the Skytech Chronos is worth a look. It upgrades you to a 2TB Gen4 NVMe SSD and 32GB DDR5 RAM, which is overkill for most people—but also really nice to have. This is a solid pick for streamers and multitaskers, but if you don’t need the extra RAM and storage, you can save money by going with the Blaze4. So you're after an AMD Radeon RX 9070 / XT? While the price is great, trying to seemingly find one at retail price is about as easy as finding a PS5 in 2020. Instead of paying inflated prices, I'd instead recommend picking up a prebuilt gaming PC—and these Skytech options are some of the best I've seen.

Prebuilts aren't just for people who don’t want to tinker. These days, buying a prebuilt can actually save you money, especially when GPU stock is this scarce. And let's be real, not everyone has the patience (or technical confidence) to put together a custom rig without something catching on fire.

To help you in your search, I've scoured Amazon for the best Skytech gaming PCs featuring the RX 9070 and RX 9070 XT, and here's what I found.

For just $1,349.99, this is the cheapest way to get your hands on an RX 9070—and honestly, it's a solid deal. You get an Intel Core i5-14400F (perfectly fine for gaming), 16GB of DDR5 RAM (6000MHz), and a 1TB NVMe SSD.

The 650W Gold PSU is technically enough for this build, but I'd prefer something a little beefier. If you plan to add more components later, you might want to upgrade the power supply. That said, if you just want a plug-and-play rig that runs 1440p games at high settings, this is a great deal.

Same specs as the Shadow, but this one comes in white. If you’re all about aesthetics and want your setup to look like a futuristic space station, this is your pick. The mesh front panel also improves airflow, which is nice because nobody likes thermal throttling.

Downside? It’s $350 more than the Shadow for basically the same internals. You’re paying for the case and cooling improvements. But hey, if looks matter, go for it.

Now we're talking. The Skytech Blaze4 swaps in the RX 9070 XT—which, by the way, clears Nvidia's RTX 5070 Ti in most benchmarks. You also get an AMD Ryzen 7 7700, a better 850W Gold PSU, and the same 16GB DDR5 RAM and 1TB SSD.

This build is $1,599.99 right now (normally $1,699.99), which makes it one of the best-value RX 9070 XT PCs I’ve seen. If you want 4K gaming without selling a kidney, this is it.

Skytech Chronos Gaming PC – $1,899.99

If you have a massive game library (or just hate deleting stuff), the Skytech Chronos is worth a look. It upgrades you to a 2TB Gen4 NVMe SSD and 32GB DDR5 RAM, which is overkill for most people—but also really nice to have.

This is a solid pick for streamers and multitaskers, but if you don’t need the extra RAM and storage, you can save money by going with the Blaze4.

Intel fans, this is your best RX 9070 XT prebuilt. But at $1,999.99, it’s not the best value on this list.

If you want an all AMD system, this version of the Rampage features Ryzen 7 9700X—which beats Intel in multi-core workloads and gaming longevity. It also has 2TB SSD storage and 32GB DDR5 RAM.
